Body and Emotion Awareness Differences (BEAD) Section 1 Introduction

Body and Emotion Awareness Differences (BEAD) Paul W. Savoca, Eddie Navarro, & Bridget L. Callaghan 2024-04-30 Section 1 Introduction This wiki contains information for the Body and Emotion Awareness Differences (BEAD) Study. Data was collected as part of Eddie Navarroâ€™s Honors Project

Section 2 Overview 2.1 Summary Body and Emotion Awareness Differences (BEAD) Wiki 2.2 Aims [TO ADD] 2.3 Background BEAD is an online study to better understand the asssociations between interoception, affective processing, and earlier life experiences (such as adversity, puberty, and trauma). It also includes outcome measures such as current depressive and anxious symptoms. Data was collected online from UCLA students using SONA.

S., Catmur, C., & Bird, G. (2020). Testing the independence of self-reported interoceptive accuracy and attention. Quarterly Journal of Experimental Psychology, 73(1), 115-133. Multidimensional Assessment of Interoceptive Awareness 2 (MAIA-2) Mehling WE, Acree M, Stewart A, Silas J, Jones A (2018) The Multidimensional Assessment of Interoceptive Awareness, Version 2 (MAIA-2). PLoS ONE 13(12): e0208034. Interoceptive Confusion Questionnaire (ICQ) CES-D Puberty & Contraceptive Questions Clare McCann Questionnaire of Unpredictability in Childhood (QUIC) Emotions as a Child Questionnaire (EAC) Toronto Alexithymia Scale (TAS-20) State Trait Anxiety Inventory (Trait; STAI-T) 3.3 Funding N/A
Section 4 Data Collection 4.1 Location 4.2 Data Storage
Section 4 Data Collection 4.1 Location All research is online using REDCap. 4.2 Data Storage The questionnaire data is stored in REDCap. Scripts and Processed Data is stored in Box.
